title: The Day of the Lord
shortSummary: 2 Peter Chapter 3 addresses the certainty of Christ’s return and the final judgment, warning against scoffers who doubt the promise of His coming. It encourages believers to live holy and godly lives while patiently awaiting the new heavens and new earth God has promised.
timeline: c. AD 65-68 - Written by the Apostle Peter near the end of his life

keyCharacters.name: Peter
keyCharacters.description: The apostle who authored this epistle, writing to encourage believers to remember the teachings of the prophets and apostles about Christ’s return.

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: Referred to as the beloved brother whose epistles also speak of the last days and are sometimes difficult to understand.

keyCharacters.name: Scoffers
keyCharacters.description: People in the last days who mock the promise of Christ’s coming and live according to their own desires.

definitions.definition: Those who mock or ridicule the promise of Christ’s return, doubting its fulfillment and living selfishly.
God’s patient endurance, showing mercy by delaying judgment to allow time for repentance.
The future time when God will bring final judgment and establish His eternal kingdom.
The basic components of the physical world, which will be destroyed by fire at the end of the age.

outline.heading: Introduction and Reminder of Prophetic Words
outline.description: Peter writes a second letter to stir believers’ pure minds by reminding them of the words spoken by the prophets and apostles concerning the last days.

outline.heading: Warning Against Scoffers and Their Ignorance
outline.description: Peter warns that scoffers will come, denying Christ’s return and ignoring God’s past judgment by flood, emphasizing God’s power in creation and judgment.

outline.heading: God’s Perspective on Time and His Patience
outline.description: Peter explains that God’s timing differs from human timing and that His apparent delay is due to His patience, desiring all to repent rather than perish.

outline.heading: The Certainty and Suddenness of the Day of the Lord
outline.description: The day of the Lord will come unexpectedly, bringing destruction by fire, but believers look forward to a new heaven and new earth where righteousness dwells.

outline.heading: Exhortation to Holy Living and Growth in Grace
outline.description: Believers are urged to live peaceably, blamelessly, and grow in grace and knowledge of Jesus, while being cautious of false teachers who twist Scripture.

application: Live with a sense of holy urgency, pursuing godliness as you await Christ’s return.
Be patient and extend grace to others, remembering God’s longsuffering desire for all to repent.
Study Scripture diligently to grow in grace and discernment, guarding against false teachings.
Maintain peace and blamelessness in your walk with Christ, so you may be found faithful at His coming.

keyVerses.text: The Lord is not slack concerning his promise, as some men count slackness; but is longsuffering to us-ward, not willing that any should perish, but that all should come to repentance.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God’s patient nature and His desire for all to repent, explaining the delay in Christ’s return.

keyVerses.text: But the day of the Lord will come as a thief in the night; in the which the heavens shall pass away with a great noise, and the elements shall melt with fervent heat, the earth also and the works that are therein shall be burned up.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes the suddenness and power of Christ’s return and the final judgment, urging readiness.

keyVerses.text: Nevertheless we, according to his promise, look for new heavens and a new earth, wherein dwelleth righteousness.
keyVerses.significance: This verse offers hope and assurance of the eternal, righteous kingdom believers eagerly await.

keyVerses.text: But grow in grace, and in the knowledge of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ. To him be glory both now and for ever. Amen.
keyVerses.significance: It calls believers to continual spiritual growth and glorifying Christ in all things.
